author: mini_mads1980
title: Great set for play
review:
This is the first of the 2015 City sets I have purchased.  It cost £17.99, which is the retail price.  

Box/Instructions

Initial thoughts of the new 2015 design is that Lego have made an improvement.  The border is crisp and the image of the set is clear and shows the Pickup with a broken down blue car attached to the back, and a rather happy driver despite the problem with his vehicle.

 

The image on the top of the box shows the two Minifigures that come with the set, with the Mechanic as the 1:1 scale image.  The two sides are the same image as the front of the box and the back has the Mechanic as the Hey! image in the top-right and five pictures that show a story of the car losing a wheel and then being attached to the truck.

Inside the box there are three numbered bags, two instruction booklets, a sticker sheet with 12 stickers and a large vehicle plate for the Pickup.

Instruction Book 1 builds the blue car and driver.  Instruction Book 2 builds the Pickup and the Mechanic, it also includes images of five new sets (including this one) and four of the 2014 sets as well as the parts list.

Parts

No new parts appear to be in the set, and what parts are present are pretty much standard in similar sets.

Minifigures

The car driver is a smart member of the public with a green pullover and a pair of trousers.  The mechanic has a beard and glasses and is in the standard overalls with printed tools in his pocket.

The build

The car only takes a couple of minutes to put together in 18 steps.  There is nothing that is going to surprise anyone in the construction, and it reminds me of one of the cars from the garage / car park (4207) that was released a couple of years ago with a few minor differences.  Once built there are only two transparent parts left.

 

The first part of the Pickup is built in thirty-two stages at the start of the second booklet.  It takes a little over five minutes to put together and builds the base of the vehicle.  The second part (steps 33 to 47) also takes a bit over five minutes to build.  The construction of the arm is nice, however there is nothing too taxing.

The completed model

The completed model has a nice playability about it, but it is lacking in a couple of areas for me.  Other models, such as 60017, 7638 and 60056 all have opening doors to the cab but this set does not.  The roofs of the vehicles are removable but this little aspect takes something away for me.  Also, the green cheeses on the side of the Pickup have an nasty gap between them, which could have been improved.

A slightly strange thing is the 2x2 with 1 stud that sits in the back of the Pickup to hold the fire extinguisher.  This may be to hold the arm of the Pickup in place, however it seems sturdy enough without it, so not sure why it is there.

Overall opinion

I like the look of the set, and I am sure kids will have hours of play with the set.  The inclusion of the car makes it more playable than 60056 as a standalone set.

author: redbeardlegoman
title: Great Tow Truck and Bonus Car!
review:
This was one the those sets that I initially thought, "I'll probably get it, because I'm a completist nut."  After I built it, however, I was quite delighted by it, and will probably come to put in on my favourites list. 

Box/Instructions

I never really have much to say about boxes and instructions.  I toss the boxes that I don't use as scrap cardboard.  I always think they should be smaller, too.  And it's good to have instructions, though I always think that more steps could be incorporated on each page.

Parts

I like that the trend continues to use Technic parts to add more function and playability to the sets.  The towing arm while simple, does the job well, and I think it has an elegance in its simplicity.  I like that functionality comes with an economy of pieces.  It also doesn't make the mechanism overly clunky.  If I had to point out one flaw, and it's very minor, it's that the lower hook portion is a bit floppy.  I imagine that in a real truck, that would be stiffer and more secure.  But, like I said, it's a minor thing.

While I don't normally have much to say about stickers, positive or negative, I really like the sticker on the hood of the truck.  I think it's a catchy and well-executed piece of graphic art. The off-centre green stripe and cluster of stars, to my mind, give hints of the personality of the driver or owner of the towing company.  I do hope to see more of this kind of realism in the future.

Minifigures

The minifigures are perhaps generic, but that's fine.  I think the artistry of the set really comes from the vehicals anyway.  Sure it's always nice to get new minifigures, or at least new parts.  But at the same time, if it keeps the cost lower, and allows me to more easily buy a different set, or a good variation on a theme, then I'm all for it.

The build

The build wasn't tricky.  But I don't really expect much challenge from City sets.  What I do enjoy, however, from set to set are the small variations, or different approaches to the same solutions.  The hood of the blue car could have easily been just a single hood piece.  But instead, it achieves a different look by using four pieces.  In the real world, cars are all basically car shaped, and the styling that sets them apart comes from exploring that same kind of variation on a theme.  I find that delightful.

The completed model

I like the blue car.  It's good to have another automobile to add to my city.  And I think it's wonderful to get a car with a tow truck set.  It makes it more playable immediately.  If this were a child's first set, they could play out a little scene right away, instead of having a great tow truck with no cars to assist.

The truck, however, is great.  It's a solid, stable build in relatively few, well-used parts.  My daughter can push it along the floor, in her enthusiasm, without all the parts falling off all the time.  The proportions of it compared to the accompanying car make it look like a powerful, dependable working vehicle.  The hood sticker gives it a human touch I can't help but find endearing.  The proportions are good.  It might not be a showcase piece, like a big old starship or castle, but I could see it sitting proudly on a shelf as that quietly excellent design I could envy the creator for.

Overall opinion

For the price you get two vehicals and two minifigures.  You get a great tow truck, and a nice little car to rescue.  Playable and able to take the exuberance of a toddler, it also looks good displayed on a shelf in any proud collection.  I'd say if you were going to get any City set this year, this is the sleeper hit.  It's going to grow on you, like it did on me.

author: andyh1984
title: Nicer than it looks on the box
review:
I had spotted this at a reduced price and wasn't sure about it but when I went back it was further reduced so I bought it, I am glad I did as its a nice set but the RRP seems a little high to me.

Box/Instructions

standard city box showing model and play features.

Parts

Nothing spectacular though the stickers for the truck are visually very eyecatching

Minifigures

2 male minifigures, man with a green jumper over blue shirt with light tan legs and the bearded, bespectacled tow truck driver with dark blue overalls over a light blue shirt wearing a blue baseball cap

The build

The car is built first and is quite basic, the truck has a little more building  involved, the whole set took me 40 leisurely minutes including applying stickers.

The completed model

It looks nice, the truck catches the eye with its colour scheme and graphics and the towing function works well for its simplicity.

Overall opinion

I like it but not enough to spend £17.99 on it but its a good set and a nice playscene for any child.
